questions.text: A urologist is teaching medical students about the causes of hydronephrosis. When discussing bilateral hydronephrosis, which of the following conditions is not typically associated with this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Unilateral Hydronephrosis

Bilateral Hydronephrosis

Extramural Causes:

  • Advanced Malignancies
    • Colorectal cancer
    • Carcinoma cervix
    • Carcinoma Prostate
  • Retroperitoneal fibrosis
  • Retrocaval Ureter (Option D)

Congenital Causes:

  • Posterior Urethral Valve (Option C ruled out)
  • Urethral atresia

Intramural Causes:

  • PUJ Obstruction
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric Stricture
  • Urothelial tumor

Acquired Causes:

  • Bladder neck stenosis (Option A ruled out)
  • BPH (Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia) (Option B ruled out)
  • CA Prostate
  • Urethral strictures

Intraluminal Causes:

  • Stone
  • Papillary Slough
  • Due to:
    • Analgesic nephropathy
    • Sickle cell anemia

questions.text: A male presents with a 3 cm stone in the middle calyx of the left kidney. Which of the following statements regarding the use of percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) in the management of this patient is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: PCNL involves creating a large flank incision to directly access the renal pelvis and remove the stone

options.label: B
options.text: PCNL is indicated for the treatment of renal stones larger than 2 cm in diameter or stones resistant to ESWL

options.label: C
options.text: PCNL is performed under general anesthesia, and the patient is required to remain immobilized for several days postoperatively

options.label: D
options.text: PCNL is contraindicated in patients with severe hydronephrosis or anatomical abnormalities of the urinary tract

questions.correct_answer: B. PCNL is indicated for the treatment of renal stones larger than 2 cm in diameter or stones resistant to ESWL

questions.text: In a 55-year-old male with sterile pyuria, flank pain, and a "moth-eaten" renal calyx appearance on CT, which test is the gold standard for confirming genitourinary tuberculosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature Details
Common symptoms Flank pain, dysuria, sterile pyuria, hematuria
Key imaging findings Moth-eaten calyces, cortical scarring, shrunken kidney
Gold standard diagnostic test Urine culture for M. tuberculosis (three early-morning samples)
Other helpful tests PCR for TB, CT urogram, IVP for structural changes
Typical CT/IVP appearance Irregular calyces, calcification, strictures, non-functioning kidney

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of renal tuberculosis presents with increased urinary frequency and lower abdominal discomfort that has gradually worsened over the past few months. Imaging studies reveal significant fibrosis and a reduced bladder size. Which of the following features is present in the advanced stage, where the bladder is contracted?

options.label: A
options.text: Golf hole around the ureteric orifice

options.label: C
options.text: The beaded appearance of the distal ureter

questions.correct_answer: A. Golf hole around the ureteric orifice

questions.text: A 38-year-old male with a history of untreated pulmonary tuberculosis presents with symptoms of dysuria, hematuria, and flank pain, and noticed a gradual worsening of his symptoms. His laboratory tests are consistent with renal impairment. Which of the following features are seen in this condition?

A 35-year-old man presents with intermittent right flank pain and a palpable mass in his right loin. His urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria. Imaging reveals the presence of unilateral hydronephrosis. Which of the following correctly describes the condition known as Dietl's crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: Sudden onset of flank pain accompanied by fever and pyuria

options.label: B
options.text: Intermittent flank pain with a palpable abdominal mass that resolves after voiding large volume of urine

options.label: C
options.text: Constant dull ache in the loin with progressive renal failure

options.label: D
options.text: Acute anuria associated with bilateral ureteric obstruction

questions.correct_answer: B. Intermittent flank pain with a palpable abdominal mass that resolves after voiding large volume of urine
questions.explanation:
Unilateral Hydronephrosis

Bilateral Hydronephrosis
  • Congenital PUJ obstruction and calculus are the most common causes
  • Male to Female ratio 2:1
  • Right side kidney is affected more commonly

From lower urinary tract obstruction:

  • Loin pain
  • Features of bladder outlet obstruction—frequency, hesitancy, poor stream
  • Kidneys are not palpable if renal failure develops early
  • Dull aching loin pain with dragging sensation or heaviness
  • Mass in the loin which moves with respiration
  • Dietl's crisis (Intermittent Hydronephrosis): Swelling in the loin after acute renal colic, disappears after passing a large volume of urine (Option B)
  • Dysuria, haematuria. If infected, fever and tenderness in the renal angle

From bilateral upper urinary tract obstruction:

  • Loin pain, mass in the loin, attacks of renal colic
  • In severe cases, features of renal failure like oliguria, edema, and hiccoughs may be present

questions.text: A 62-year-old diabetic man presents with fever, flank pain, and a palpable mass in his left loin. Initial ultrasound reveals a fluid collection associated with the left kidney. Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to the probable diagnosis of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Pyonephrosis is commonly seen in patients with hydronephrosis due to renal obstruction

options.label: B
options.text: Pyonephrosis can spread by cortical extension & hematogenous route

options.label: C
options.text: Pyonephrosis involves the collection of pus inside the kidney

options.label: D
options.text: Percutaneous nephrostomy is the treatment of choice for elderly and diabetic patients

questions.correct_answer: B. Pyonephrosis can spread by cortical extension & hematogenous route
questions.explanation:
Feature

Pyonephrosis

Perinephric Abscess

Definition
  • Destruction of renal parenchyma followed by pus collection inside kidneys (Option C ruled out)
  • Collection of pus around the kidney
  • Spread by 2 routes: Cortical extension and Hematogenous spread (Option B)

Most Common Cause
  • Renal stones leading to hydronephrosis (the most common cause of obstruction) (Option A ruled out)
  • E. coli > Proteus
  • Urine culture positive in 1/3rd of cases
  • Blood culture positive in 50% of cases

Clinical Features
  • Fever
  • Anemia
  • Mass in loin
  • Pain
  • Tenderness in flanks
  • Fever

Diagnosis
  • USG
  • USG/CT

Management
  • IV antibiotics + Drainage
  • Percutaneous nephrostomy (Elderly, diabetic, etc) (Option D ruled out)
  • For Non-Functioning Kidney: Nephrectomy
  • IV antibiotics + percutaneous drainage
  • If the patient does not respond after percutaneous drainage, then go for Open drainage / Nephrectomy

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with poorly controlled diabetes presents with fever, flank pain, and vomiting. Initial investigations reveal a kidney infection. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen in Emphysematous Pyelonephritis but not in Xanthogranulomatous Pyelonephritis?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of Proteus as the causative organism

options.label: B
options.text: Air within the kidney or perinephric region on imaging

options.label: D
options.text: Foamy lipid-laden histiocytes in renal parenchyma

questions.correct_answer: B. Air within the kidney or perinephric region on imaging
questions.explanation:
Emphysematous Pyelonephritis

Xanthogranulomatous Pyelonephritis

Definition

Presence of air around the kidney or within the kidney (Option B)

Chronic bacterial infection

Causative Organism

E. coli, Klebsiella

Proteus (most common) (Option A ruled out)

Associations

Diabetes (due to low immunity), Female gender

Associated with Struvite stones (Option C ruled out)

Clinical Features

Flank pain, Fever, Vomiting

Flank pain, Fever with chills and rigor, Flank Mass, Bacteriuria

Investigation of Choice

CT scan

CECT (Bear’s paw sign)

Findings

The presence of air in renal parenchyma and parenchyma of surrounding structures
  • Presence of Xanthoma cells in renal parenchyma (Foamy lipid-laden histiocytes) (Option D ruled out)
  • Mimics Clear cell variant of RCC

Treatment
  • IV antibiotics
  • Resuscitation
  • Control blood glucose
  • Percutaneous drainage if urinary tract obstruction is present
  • Nephrectomy
  • Initially, Partial Nephrectomy
  • If not possible, total Nephrectomy

Image

This computed tomography (CT) scan demonstrates extensive destruction of the right kidney with intraparenchymal gas on the right, obliterating the renal architecture. The left kidney is normal.

Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis with the ‘bear’s paw sign’

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of recurrent renal stones is scheduled for laser-based intracorporeal lithotripsy to treat a 2 cm stone in the renal pelvis. Which of the following lasers is most commonly used for intracorporeal lithotripsy procedures?
questions.explanation:
Types of Intracorporeal Lithotripsy

Description

Laser Lithotripsy
  • Holmium: YAG laser
  • Used in Renal stones and BPH
  • Stone vaporization by photo-thermal mechanism
  • Costly but safe

Electrohydraulic Lithotripsy (EHL)
  • Cheap but low safety margin
  • Mainly used for bladder stones

Ultrasonic Lithotripsy
  • Not commonly used

Ballistic Lithotripsy
  • Not commonly used

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of radiolucent renal stone?
questions.explanation:
Stone Type

Features

Image

Calcium Oxalate
  • The most common type of stone (60–85% of all stones) ; Radiopaque
  • Associated with hypercalciuria, hypercalcaemia, hyperoxaluria, hyperuricosuria, and hypocitraturia
  • Types: monohydrate (dumbbell shaped) , dihydrate (envelope shaped)

 


 

Calcium Phosphate
  • Pure calcium phosphate stones are rare
  • Types include apatite and brushite stones
  • Apatite stones are seen with infection; brushite stones are associated with distal renal tubular acidosis

Struvite
  • Aka staghorn calculi / Triple phosphate stone (Ca, Mg, NH4+, Phosphate)
  • Radiopaque
  • Infection stones that form in alkaline urine due to urease-producing bacteria (e.g., Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia, Enterobacter)

Cystine
  • Radiopaque, Constitute approximately 1% of stones
  • Result from cystinuria, an autosomal recessive inherited disease that causes decreased reabsorption of cystine
  • Very hard stones due to disulfide bonds

Uric Acid
  • Radiolucent
  • Promoted by hyperuricosuria, which can be caused by conditions like gout and myeloproliferative disorders
  • Precipitates in acidic urine and remains soluble in alkaline urine

questions.text: A male underwent ESWL for a 2 cm renal stone 4 weeks ago. Imaging now reveals multiple small stone fragments (street of stone) in the ureter. Which of the following statements regarding the management of this condition is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Urgent ureteroscopy should be performed to remove the obstructing stone fragments

options.label: B
options.text: Conservative management with alpha-blocker therapy is the first-line approach

options.label: C
options.text: Repeat ESWL is the preferred option to further fragment the retained stone pieces

options.label: D
options.text: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy is the treatment of choice to clear the Steinstrasse

questions.correct_answer: B. Conservative management with alpha-blocker therapy is the first-line approach

questions.text: A male presents with a 10 mm stone in the lower pole of the left kidney. Regarding the use of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) for this patient, which of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: ESWL works by generating focused shock waves that pass through the body and fragment the stone

options.label: B
options.text: ESWL is contraindicated in patients with significant skeletal deformities or obesity

options.label: C
options.text: ESWL can be performed on stones less than 2 cm in diameter for optimal fragmentation

options.label: D
options.text: Post-ESWL, the patient is encouraged to ambulate soon after the procedure to facilitate stone passage

questions.correct_answer: C. ESWL can be performed on stones less than 2 cm in diameter for optimal fragmentation

questions.text: A male presents with a 5 mm lower-ureteric stone and no hydronephrosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Trial of conservative management with medical expulsive therapy

questions.correct_answer: D. Trial of conservative management with medical expulsive therapy

questions.text: A 30 years old male presents with recurrent episodes of right flank pain and hematuria. Ultrasonography and plain abdominal radiography are inconclusive for renal stones. Which of the following statements regarding the use of radionuclide scans in the evaluation of this patient is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Technetium-99m dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is the preferred modality to diagnose renal stones

options.label: B
options.text: Gallium-67 citrate scan has higher sensitivity and specificity than DMSA scan for detecting renal stones

options.label: C
options.text: Radionuclide scans are exclusively reserved for patients with impaired renal function

options.label: D
options.text: Radionuclide scans can distinguish between obstructing and non-obstructing renal stones

questions.correct_answer: D. Radionuclide scans can distinguish between obstructing and non-obstructing renal stones

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is considered the gold standard for diagnosing renal stones and can identify both radiopaque and radiolucent stones?

A 35-year-old woman presents with recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs), persistent back pain, and hematuria. Imaging reveals a large, branched stone occupying a significant portion of her right kidney. Urinalysis shows alkaline pH, the presence of bacteria, and crystals as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely composition of this stone?

A 42-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. Imaging reveals that he has a renal stone lodged in the middle third of his ureter. He describes the pain as radiating to his hypogastrium. Which nerve is responsible for the radiation of pain to the hypogastrium?

A 50-year-old man with a history of HIV, on ART, presents to the emergency department with severe flank pain, hematuria, and difficulty urinating. Recent imaging studies reveal the presence of renal stones. Which of the following ART drugs is commonly associated with the development of renal stones?
